ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course provided an in-depth study of Dante's Divine Comedy. No prior knowledge of the Comedy or Italian literature is expected
learned a lot about Dante and learned how much more there is to learn! Great course and super interesting, coming from someone who never read Dante and knew nothing about the Comedy

In this course I learned how to read and analyze Dante's Comedy beginning with his previous work in the Vita Nuova. After developing a basic understanding of his form, style, historical context, and influences we were then able to bring this work into our own reality and draw connections between Dante's commentary and contemporary figures.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths: Simona and Teresa are super sweet and make you think of connections you wouldn't otherwise
weakeness: I wish the course was a year long! There's so much to the Comedy that a semester just isn't enough

Given the difficulty of transferring a seminar into the virtual format, I thought this course was very effective in fostering a community and facilitating lively discussions even via Zoom. I also really appreciated how Professor Lorenzini used all the tools at her disposal to ensure we were not overtaken by Zoom fatigue, this included guest lectures, visuals, a virtual tour of the art gallery, presentations, and more. I do however wish that this class could have been taught as a year long course. While I learned a great deal about Dante, it is difficult to understand the weight of his work if you do not have a grasp of the Aeneid, the Bible, etc. While we were exposed to other texts and always encouraged to pursue our own research I think that a course on Dante must also include an examination of the classic writers that are so present in his Comedy.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: As I mentioned before, I was quite engaged in this class because of the way in which Professor Lorenzini incorporated all the tools that were at her disposal.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course as long as you have some interest in medieval literature and classic literature.
Yes absolutely take this class!!! Everyone should take a class on Dante before leaving Yale!
For sure! Anyone who likes a good read with connections to everything from philosophy, theology to the classics and sciences
